channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2015 The New York Times Company

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Film Highlights Air Pollution’s Broad Reach
item.description: “Smog Journeys” follows the lives of two Chinese families: one a mining family in rural Hebei Province and the other a cosmopolitan family in hyper-urban Beijing.
item.dc:creator: By AMY QIN
item.media:description: A steel plant in the Handan area of Hebei Province, south of Beijing. A new film tries to show that all Chinese, regardless of socioeconomic status or geography, are affected by dirty air.

item.title: Saudis Expand Regional Power as Others Falter
item.description: Rather than undermine the Saudi dynasty, the chaos across the region appears instead to have lifted the monarchy to unrivaled power and influence.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK
item.media:description: Abdel Fattah el-Sisi, left, the president of Egypt, with King Abdullah of Saudi Arabia in June. The king, who died last week, gave Egypt $12 billion in assistance after Mr. Sisi came to power.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Hong Kong Editor, Attacked Last Year, Expresses Hope for Future of News Media
item.description: Kevin Lau Chun-to, still using crutches and hobbling almost a year after he was attacked with a cleaver, said closer ties with mainland China came with great risks, but expressed hope for press freedom.
item.dc:creator: By CHRIS BUCKLEY and ALAN WONG
item.media:description: Kevin Lau Chun-to in January 2014, after his dismissal as editor of the Hong Kong newspaper Ming Pao.

item.title: Disillusioned by War, Israeli Soldiers Muted in 1967 Are Given Fuller Voice
item.description: As the International Criminal Court considers a war crimes investigation in the recent Gaza conflict, a new documentary film is showcasing previously unaired accounts of the brutal experiences of an earlier generation of Israeli soldiers.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN
item.media:description: Mor Loushy, director of "Censored Voices," a new film about the 1967 war.

item.title: At Least 18 Die in Egyptian Violence
item.description: After nearly 18 months of recurring police shootings at street protests since the military takeover in 2013, it was the deaths of two others killed over the weekend that most captured Egypt’s attention.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK
item.media:description: Shaimaa al-Sabbagh receiving assistance after she was shot in clashes with the police in Cairo on Saturday. She later died.

item.title: W.H.O. Members Endorse Resolution to Improve Response to Health Emergencies
item.description: Key provisions include creating a global cadre of emergency health workers, establishing a fund that could be tapped quickly, and support for the development of treatments for emerging infectious diseases.
item.dc:creator: By SHERI FINK

item.title: The Vatican Switches to Balloons for Peace
item.description: Balloons, not doves, were released as a gesture of peace on Sunday in St. Peter’s Square, a year after an attack by a gull and a crow on the symbolic birds set off protests by animal protection groups.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Memo From Dresden: German Quandary of How to Deal With Anti-Immigration Movement
item.description: Local leaders have started engaging with supporters of the movement, despite concerns about its roots and backing from neo-Nazis and extremists.
item.dc:creator: By MELISSA EDDY
item.media:description: A rally Sunday by the Patriotic Europeans Against the Islamization of the West, known as Pegida, drew thousands in Dresden, where the movement has grown.

item.title: Obama Clears a Hurdle to Better Ties With India
item.description: President Obama came to an agreement with Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India on nuclear energy, renewed a 10-year defense pact, agreed to joint military hardware production and resolved to work with India to reduce the threat of greenhouse gas emissions.
item.dc:creator: By PETER BAKER and ELLEN BARRY
item.media:description: Mr. Obama and Michelle Obama greeting guests before dinner ceremonies hosted by President Pranab Mukherjee, left.

item.title: World Briefing: Libya: Gunmen Abduct an Official
item.description: Gunmen have kidnapped the deputy foreign minister of Libya’s internationally recognized government, the interior minister said Sunday.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing: Central African Republic: Kidnappers Seize Government Minister in Capital
item.description: The minister for youth and sport was kidnapped on Sunday by gunmen in the capital, Bangui, and a second minister narrowly escaped capture in a town to the north, officials said.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: Two Japanese Hostages, as Different as Can Be, Linked by Fate in Syria
item.description: The surviving hostage is a respected journalist, while the other man was a lost soul who had attempted suicide and seemed to become unhinged by setbacks in life.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By MARTIN FACKLER
item.media:description: Shoichi Yukawa, father of the hostage Haruna Yukawa, was interviewed Sunday at home near Tokyo.

item.title: World Briefing: Iraq: Bombings Kill at Least 15 People
item.description: A string of bombings ripped mainly through commercial areas in the capital, Baghdad, on Sunday, killing at least 15 people and wounding dozens, officials said.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: The Philippines: Police and Rebels Clash
item.description: More than 30 police commandos were killed in a clash with Muslim insurgents on Sunday in the southern Philippines.
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Shifting Alliances Play Out Behind Closed Doors in Yemen
item.description: A takeover led by Houthi rebels is part of a structure of shifting alliances and warring interests in Yemen that are now the subject of difficult negotiations.
item.dc:creator: By MONA EL-NAGGAR
item.media:description: Gunmen of the Houthi rebel group, wearing military uniforms, standing guard outside the headquarters of Yemen’s Parliament in Sana on Sunday.

item.title: Chitresh Das, Influential Performer and Educator of Indian Dance, Dies at 70
item.description: Mr. Das helped popularize kathak, one of the most prominent forms of classical Indian dance and the only one that has roots in both Muslim and Hindu traditions.
item.dc:creator: By ROSLYN SULCAS
item.media:description: Through his schools and his dance company, Chitresh Das, shown in 2004, popularized a classical form of Indian dance known as kathak.

item.title: World Briefing: Indonesia: Jet’s Wreckage Sinks Again
item.description: The second attempt to lift the fuselage of the crashed AirAsia jetliner failed Sunday as the wreckage sank back to the ocean floor when a rope linking the lifting balloons broke.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Open Source: Greek Leftists Adopt Patti Smith Anthem ‘People Have the Power’ as Their Own
item.description: An American rock song has become something of an unofficial anthem for Greek populists.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY
item.media:description: A screenshot of the left-wing Syriza party's first Twitter update after the polls closed in Greece on Sunday night.

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: France's Sunday Pirouettes
item.description: A debate over shopping hours has turned Socialist against Socialist and united Catholic clerics and their critics.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT ZARETSKY

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Political Sabotage over a Deal with Iran
item.description: Those who oppose any diplomacy between Iran and the West are already seeking to end the process altogether.
item.dc:creator: By ELLIE GERANMAYEH
